docs.lead_paragraph: Social Security gets all the attention, but the real budget busters among the entitlement programs are Medicare and Medicaid, which cover more than 1 in 4 Americans.
docs.abstract: As President Bush seeks to eliminate the federal budget deficit by 2012, his new budget proposal includes trimming $70 billion from Medicare and Medicaid over five years.
docs.snippet: As President Bush seeks to eliminate the federal budget deficit by 2012, his new budget proposal includes trimming $70 billion from Medicare and Medicaid over five years.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even some administration officials say they cannot imagine the $70 billion cuts being approved.

headline.main: Bush Seeks Big Medicare and Medicaid Saving
headline.print_headline: Bush Seeks Big Medicare and Medicaid Saving, but Faces Hard Fight

docs.snippet: Even some administration officials say they cannot imagine the $70 billion cuts being approved.

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House and the new Congress still have a chance to create a bipartisan consensus on trade. For the good of the American economy, and for the good of the world’s poorest nations, they should seize it.
docs.snippet: The White House and the new Congress still have a chance to create a bipartisan consensus on trade. For the good of the American economy, and for the good of the world’s poorest nations, they should seize it.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Christian ministry that helps its members pay one another’s medical bills won an important round in its legal battle with insurance regulators.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Eliot Spitzer wants to turn away from a financial system that rewards political favorites to one that focuses on what regular people actually get when New York spends a stunning $120 billion.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Eliot Spitzer's budget contains the seeds of an epic battle — $1.2 billion a year in cuts — that could make everything else he wants harder to attain.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Your MasterCard or Your Life,'' by Bob Herbert (column, Jan. 22): The problem of the uninsured and the rising costs of health care are critical national issues that deserve serious and thoughtful consideration. Suggesting that credit cards are to blame sidesteps the issue. Credit cards have provided enormous benefits to the United States economy, making transactions more convenient and secure and assuring small businesses, including doctors, of payment.
docs.abstract: Letter from Edward Yingling, president and chief executive of American Bankers Assn, contends blaming credit cards for problems of medically uninsured is sidestepping problem (Jan 22 Bob Herbert Op-Ed column)
